Advancements in rare earth mullite oxides (AMn2O5) for catalytic oxidation: Structure, activity and design strategies Yaohui Dun Writing – original draft Project administration Conceptualization Yanfei Liu Writing – original draft Investigation Jie Xu Investigation Data curation Lihong Xie Investigation Chun Du Writing – review & editing Funding acquisition ⁎ Bin Shan Writing – review & editing Funding acquisition ⁎ State Key Laboratory of Materials Processing and Die & Mould Technology, School of Materials Science and Engineering, Huazhong University of Science and Technology, Wuhan, Hubei 430074, People’s Republic of China State Key Laboratory of Materials Processing and Die & Mould Technology, School of Materials Science and Engineering, Huazhong University of Science and Technology Wuhan Hubei 430074 People’s Republic of China State Key Laboratory of Materials Processing and Die & Mould Technology, School of Materials Science and Engineering, Huazhong University of Science and Technology, Wuhan 430074, Hubei, People’s Republic of China ⁎ Corresponding authors. The development of rare earth catalysts is expected to reduce the dependence on noble metal catalysts in mobile and stationary sources. The AMn2O5 mullite oxide is a category of rare earth metal oxides for the catalytic oxidation of environmental pollutants, in which the A-site cations are the rare earth cations. The coexistence of the diverse Mn ions and the exposed Mn-Mn dimers in AMn2O5 mullite oxides contribute to the excellent catalytic performance for various catalytic reactions. Herein, the crystal structure and the identification of lattice oxygen of AMn2O5 mullite oxides have been discussed. Meanwhile, a comprehensive understanding of the activity and the thermal stability of AMn2O5 mullite oxides has been investigated. As a group of rare earth catalysts, the representing modification strategies with their advantages have been summarized to guide the rational design of next-generation mullite oxide catalysts. To gain a deeper understanding of AMn2O5 mullite oxides as heterogeneous catalysts, we have reviewed the publications in catalytic purification of vehicle exhaust and catalytic oxidation of volatile organic compounds, accompanied by the exploration of corresponding reaction mechanisms and the analysis of applied modification strategies. Furthermore, the perspective research direction of AMn2O5 mullite oxide catalysts has been outlined to inspire more valuable research work. Graphical Abstract Keywords Rare earth catalyst Mullite oxide Modification strategy Vehicle exhaust Volatile organic compound Research advance Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Over the past decade, due to the special electronic configuration of rare earth elements, rare earth materials with unique physical and chemical properties have been widely applied in a variety of advanced technologies with an increasing demand [1–3]. In the field of heterogeneous catalysis, the localization and underfilling 4f electrons make rare earth materials obtain intrinsic chemical activity in catalytic reactions [4–6]. Rare earth catalysts perform excellent performance in the catalytic treatment of environmental pollutants, especially in the treatment of exhaust gas [7]. Because of their good oxygen storage/release capacity, excellent thermal stability and anti-poisoning ability, rare earth catalysts are expected to be one of the alternative candidates to noble metal catalysts [8–10]. With stricter emission standards, it is valuable to design new rare earth catalysts to broaden the prospect in the catalytic treatment of mobile and stationary sources. Mn-based mullite-type complex metal oxides with the general formula AMn2O5, belonging to the family of orthorhombic aluminosilicate mullite [11–13], have emerged as promising catalysts applied in heterogeneous catalysis [14–16]. It is well accepted that the A-site cation primarily comprises bismuth cations and rare earth cations except cerium and promethium cations [17–22]. In 2012, Wang and co-workers [23] first reported the (Sm,Gd)Mn2O5 mixed-phase oxides and demonstrated their potential in the catalytic oxidation of gaseous pollutants. According to their experimental and theoretical calculation results, the prepared Mn-based mullite oxide catalyst showed excellent catalytic performance in NO oxidation, when compared with the conventional Pt/Al2O3 catalysts. This work indicated the potential of mullite oxides as non-precious metal catalysts and it is valuable to further broaden their application in other heterogenous catalytic reactions. After that, a large number of studies have been steadily carried out to reveal the structure-property relationship and explore various modification strategies in such category rare earth mullite oxide catalysts [24–27]. In AMn2O5 mullite oxides, the crystallographic cell is the orthorhombic unit cell and the space-group symbol is Pbam [28–30]. Fig. 1 shows the crystal structure and three typical low-index crystal surfaces in AMn2O5 mullite oxides. The A-site cations with large size exist in the 3+ oxidation state occupying 4g Wyckoff sites, and are connected with eight adjacent oxygen atoms, forming the A3+O8 polyhedrons in parallel along the a-b plane [18,31,32]. As for Mn ions, there are two types of Mn ions with the 3+ and 4+ oxidation states in equal ratios. The Mn4+ ions are located in the 4f Wyckoff sites and connected to six adjacent oxygen atoms, forming the Mn4+O6 octahedrons. The adjacent Mn4+O6 octahedrons contact with each other in an edge-sharing way in parallel to the c axis, forming an octahedral infinite chain. The distance between adjacent Mn4+ ions is so short that Mn-Mn dimers are exposed on the surface [14,24,33]. Meanwhile, the Mn3+ ions occupy the 4h Wyckoff sites, and are linked with five adjacent oxygen atoms, forming the Mn3+O5 distorted square-pyramid polyhedrons [17,34,35]. There are four adjacent Mn4+O6 octahedrons and another Mn3+O5 polyhedron connecting with one Mn3+O5 polyhedron simultaneously. In the Mn3+O5 polyhedron, the individual oxygen atom over the square bottom is shared by the edge-sharing site of two adjacent Mn4+O6 octahedrons. The two oxygen atoms on the side of square bottom in the Mn3+O5 polyhedron are connected with the separated sites belonging to another two adjacent Mn4+O6 octahedrons, while the residual two oxygen atoms are connected with the square bottom sites of one Mn3+O5 polyhedron. By this way, a pair of adjacent Mn3+O5 polyhedrons interconnects with the neighboring Mn4+O6 octahedral chains to generate a network frame structure [36], where the large A-site cations are distributed in the void between connected Mn-based polyhedrons. The coexistence of diverse Mn ions leads to the formation of four types of non-equivalent lattice oxygen sites which are denoted by O1, O2, O3, and O4, respectively [24]. As shown in Fig. 1, O1 site is connected to one Mn4+ ion and one Mn3+ ion, located at the place where the square bottom of a Mn3+O5 polyhedron is joined to the vertex of a Mn4+O6 octahedron. O2 site is connected to two Mn3+ ions, located at the sharing edge of two adjacent connected Mn3+O5 polyhedrons. O4 site is connected to two Mn4+ ions, located at the sharing edge of two adjacent connected Mn4+O6 octahedrons. Additionally, O3 site is the unique site, as it is the only position that bonds to one Mn3+ ion and two Mn4+ ions simultaneously. It is located at the place where the square bottom of one Mn3+O5 polyhedron is joined to the common vertex of two Mn4+O6 octahedrons. Compared with other lattice oxygen sites, the calculated lower oxygen vacancy formation energy at the O3 site indicates that oxygen at this site is easier to dissociate from the lattice forming stable oxygen vacancy at original position, which can serve as active center to activate gaseous oxygen [24]. Herein, we have reviewed the advantages of mullite oxides when compared to other simple or complex metal oxides, and outlined the current status of rare earth mullite oxide catalysts in this review. The origin of their catalytic performance is explored, combined with the detailed structural characteristics and theoretical calculation. The existing modification strategies applied in mullite oxide catalysts have been summarized, aiming to enhance the specific surface area, oxygen mobility, interfacial interaction, reaction selectivity and so on. Moreover, the applications of mullite oxides as heterogeneous catalysts are discussed in catalytic treatment of vehicle exhaust and catalytic oxidation of volatile organic compounds (VOCs). In the end, the challenges and perspectives of mullite oxide catalysts are proposed to provide new ideas for researchers to carry out rational design of rare earth catalysts. 2 Origin of catalytic performance of Mn-based mullite oxide catalysts The unique mullite crystal structure features, including skeleton structure within Mn4+O6 octahedron chains, diverse Mn ions and exposed Mn-Mn dimers, are strongly correlated with the outstanding catalytic performance. A profound understanding of the structure-property relationship in AMn2O5 is essential to revealing the origin of the intrinsic chemical activity and achieving the rational design of mullite oxide catalysts with better catalytic performance for stricter emission standards. 2.1 Thermal stability Transition metal oxides such as Co3O4 and MnO2, despite owning a comparable catalytic performance to those of noble metal catalysts, usually face the problem of phase transition leading to the degradation of the catalytic performance [37,38]. AMn2O5 with the skeleton structure consisting of Mn4+O6 octahedrons and Mn3+O5 distorted square-pyramid polyhedrons, performs an excellent thermal stability making it survive even under harsh working conditions such as high temperatures [16,39,40]. For instance, based on the state diagram of the Sm-Mn-O system, Yankin et al. [41] adopted the static method combined with the XRD analysis at different temperatures and pressures to explore the thermal stability of SmMn2O5. According to the results, the calculated standard enthalpy of formation in SmMn2O5 was −2150.91 kJ/mol, much smaller than −1458.706 kJ/mol of SmMnO3, indicating that the thermal stability of mullite oxides was better than perovskite oxides. This study strongly supports the conclusion that mullite oxides possess a good thermal stability, which serves as a necessary premise for the application of mullite oxide catalysts under practical conditions. It is considered that the A-site cations occupying the void between structural channels can stabilize the skeleton structure, contributing to the good thermal stability of AMn2O5 [16,42,43]. The effect of the A-site cations in regulating the Mn-O bond strength of AMn2O5 has been recognized. In the previous study of Kagomiya et al. [32] they explored the change of the crystal lattice of AMn2O5 with different A-site cations by the Rietveld analysis. They revealed the dependence of the lattice parameters on the A-site cationic radius. As the A-site cationic radius increased, the crystal lattice of AMn2O5 tended to become larger on the a-b plane while there was no significant change along the c axis. The non-uniform deformation of the crystal lattice of AMn2O5 affected the length of Mn-O bonds, which was related to the Mn-O bond strength. This work offers a theoretical foundation for elucidating the correlation between the A-site cations and the thermal stability of AMn2O5. Based on density functional theory (DFT) calculations, Li et al. [39] evaluated the thermal stability of AMn2O5 with different A-site rare earth cations including Y3+, Sm3+, Gd3+, Pr3+, and Bi3+ cations. By comparing the decomposition temperature and the thermal stable region, GdMn2O5 owned the best thermal stability with a decomposition temperature of 1196 ℃, as seen in Fig. 2(a). This study concludes that the size of A-site ions affects the strength of Mn-O bonds in AMn2O5. Specifically, a smaller A-site cationic radius typically corresponds to a greater thermal stability. Therefore, varying the A-site cations is beneficial to improve the thermal stability of AMn2O5. 2.2 Catalytic activity Considerable research has been carried out to reveal the origin of the catalytic activity of AMn2O5 mullite oxide catalysts. It is widely accepted that the exposed Mn-Mn dimers and the abundant lattice oxygen play important roles in determining the intrinsic catalytic activity of AMn2O5 [24,33,46]. In this section, to explore the catalytic behavior of AMn2O5, we have made a comprehensive discussion about the features of the Mn-Mn dimers and the lattice oxygen using NO oxidation as a model reaction. 2.2.1 Mn-Mn dimer The concept of the Mn-Mn dimers was first proposed by Wang et al. in 2012, in which the Mn-Mn dimers on the stepped surface of SmMn2O5 were regarded as the main active sites to activate gaseous O2, forming active oxygen species covering the Mn-Mn dimers [23]. A complete reaction path was proposed where a NO gas molecular was easily adsorbed on the Mn-Mn dimer and interacted with an activated oxygen to from the nitrite. Two N-O bonds were broken in turn to release a NO2 gas molecular, which left a bridged oxygen on the Mn-Mn dimer to activate gaseous O2 in the next reaction cycle. During the whole reaction process, the Mn-Mn dimers on the SmMn2O5 surface played a critical role in NO oxidation. To explore the configuration of the Mn-Mn dimers, Thampy et al. [33] studied the difference in active sites between SmMn2O5 and SmMnO3 in NO oxidation. The tested catalytic activity of SmMn2O5 was superior to that of SmMnO3 with the nearly equal active site density. As shown in Fig. 2(b), the distance between two adjacent Mn4+ ions in SmMn2O5 was 2.85 Å. The short distance formed the Mn-Mn dimers as active sites for SmMn2O5. Differently, the distance between two adjacent Mn3+ ions in SmMnO3 was 3.91 Å, which was too long to form a dimer structure. Therefore, the active sites for SmMnO3 most likely corresponded to isolated Mn3+ ions. The difference in the active sites affected the stability of nitrates, and the Mn-Mn dimers performed actively in decomposing nitrates at low temperature, leading to the better catalytic activity of SmMn2O5. Besides, the Mn-Mn dimers could serve as active sites to anchor metal atoms for constructing the functional interface, which was reported by Liu et al. [47] The electronic interaction in the Pt/Mn2 trimers facilitated the activation of gaseous O2. These studies indicate that the exposed Mn-Mn dimers on the AMn2O5 surface serve as the critical active sites in catalytic reactions. 2.2.2 Lattice oxygen There are a lot of studies focusing on the lattice oxygen to illustrate the origin of the catalytic activity of AMn2O5. For example, Shan and co-workers [24] explored the chemical properties of non-equivalent lattice oxygen in the typical low-index crystal surfaces. Among all the crystal surfaces, the (100)3+, (001)4+, and (010)4+ surfaces were regarded as potentially active surfaces due to the better activation ability of gaseous O2. The variance of surface chemistry on these active surfaces led to different catalytic behaviors in NO oxidation. On the (100)3+ surface, the exposed Mn3+ ions served as active sites to activate gaseous O2, then NO interacted with the active oxygen species to form NO2, which was dominated by the ER mechanism. Differently, the existence of Mn4+ ions on the (001)4+ and the (010)4+ surfaces was beneficial to the dissociation of adsorbed oxygen into active oxygen species, which affected the catalytic behaviors of the crystal surfaces. The (010)4+ surface with the Mn-Mn dimers obeyed the ER mechanism along the bridge-MnO channel, and the (001)4+ surface with the isolated Mn4+ ions contributed to NO oxidation through the synergistic Eley−Rideal (ER) and Mars-van Krevelen (MvK) mechanisms. This work indicates that the arrangements of the lattice oxygen and Mn ions on the crystal surfaces of AMn2O5 have an impact on the reaction mechanism in NO oxidation. To investigate the reaction mechanism under practical conditions, Yang et al. [35] adopted a first principles-based microkinetic study to simulate the process of NO oxidation on the (010)4+ surface of SmMn2O5 under experimental temperature and pressure conditions. The coverage of the critical adsorbates as a function of temperature was established to explore the possible reaction mechanisms in NO oxidation. The results indicated that the MvK mechanism played a major role in NO oxidation at temperatures above 77 ℃, while the ER mechanism contributed to NO oxidation at temperatures below 77 ℃ in SmMn2O5. In addition to the conventional mechanism, a cooperative MvK mechanism based on multiple oxygen sites was proposed by Julia and co-workers [44] to explain the catalytic behavior of SmMn2O5 in NO oxidation. As depicted in Fig. 2(c), this cooperative MvK mechanism emphasized that the neighboring lattice oxygen pairs participated in the oxidation of NO together. At the beginning, a NO gas molecular was adsorbed on a pair of neighboring lattice oxygen sites to form a bridging nitrate, which subsequently transformed into a monodentate nitrate consuming a lattice oxygen atom and leaving an oxygen vacancy. Then the formed monodentate nitrate decomposed to a NO2 gas molecular to release and the oxygen vacancy activated gaseous O2 to fill it up. Furthermore, the role of oxygen vacancy was investigated in the cooperative MvK mechanism by the time-dependent FTIR [48]. The IR peak at 1182 cm−1 was observed in SmMn2O5, which represented a relatively unstable nitrite. For a pair of neighboring oxygen sites, if they were both lattice oxygen sites, the stable bridging nitrate as the intermediate species was formed. Otherwise, if one of them was a lattice oxygen site and the other one was an oxygen vacancy, the stable nitrite as the intermediate species was formed and interacted with another adjacent nitrite. It was considered that the oxygen vacancy induced the rotation of the adsorbed NO to form the nitrite on the SmMn2O5 surface. 2.2.3 Lattice vibration It is reported that the energy transference occurs through phonon for breaking molecular bonds when the lattice vibration of catalysts is coupled with the vibration of adsorbed molecular, facilitating the catalysis process [49–51]. Recently, Zhao et al. [45] proposed the phonon resonance catalysis for understanding the catalytic behavior of YMn2O5 for NO oxidation, as depicted in Fig. 2(d). On the YMn2O5 surface, the asymmetric bending of Mnoct-Ooct_s and the bond stretch of Mnoct-Ooct_apex-Mnpry were confirmed to couple with the vibration of adsorbed O2 and -O-NO2 intermediate species, respectively. As the resonance occurred, the phonon energy from the above lattice vibrations was transferred to intermediate species, leading to the increase of their vibrational amplitudes along the reaction path of NO oxidation. During this process, the entropy of the reactants increased and the Gibbs energy of activation decreased, thus accelerating the NO oxidation process. This work provides new perspectives to understand catalysis processes on AMn2O5 surfaces. 3 Material optimizations of Mn-based mullite oxide catalysts In this section, commonly utilized modification strategies when preparing mullite oxide or mullite composite heterogeneous catalysts, have been systematically discussed in turn, including morphology control, composition regulation, interfacial decoration, mixed-phase construction as well as acid treatment. We have summarized the representing modification strategies and analyzed their advantages to guide the rational design of mullite oxide catalysts applied in different catalytic reactions. 3.1 Morphology control The formation of mullite-type materials usually requires a high temperature to ensure the crystalline, which led to the aggregation of powder and reduced the specific surface area [52]. Thampy et al. [26] reported that with the increase of the calcination temperature from 750 ℃ to 1000 ℃, the specific surface area of SmMn2O5 decreased from 23.6 m2/g to 5.1 m2/g, accompanied by the increase of the particle size. The decrease of the specific surface area resulted in the decrease of the exposed Mn-Mn dimers and the active surface oxygen species, which had a negative impact on the catalytic activity of SmMn2O5. Therefore, it is effective to enhance the catalytic activity of mullite oxide catalysts by enlarging the specific surface area. The simple way of increasing specific surface area is to control the morphology of mullite oxide catalysts by optimizing the existing synthesis route. Besides, some new synthesis methods have been reported to construct porous structure in the inner of mullite oxide, which promoted the interaction with reactants. The detailed data of the specific surface area, pore size and pore volume of mullite oxides with different morphologies reported in the literature are listed in Table 1. Hydrothermal methods have attracted tremendous attention due to their advantages of process simplicity and low temperature [27]. Comprehensive research on adjusting synthesis parameters of hydrothermal methods, including hydrothermal temperature, holding time, pH value and so on, has been conducted to tune the morphology of mullite oxides for increasing their specific surface area. For example, as depicted in Fig. 3(a), Zhang et al. [59] reported that a sea urchin-like SmMn2O5/MnO2 composite mullite oxide with the specific surface area of 149.35 m2/g was obtained by keeping its precursor at 200 ℃ for 16 hours. Rani et al. [60] adopted a modified hydrothermal method to synthesize SmMn2O5 hollow long nano-cuboids by extending the holding time to 48 hours at 180 ℃, as shown in Fig. 3(b). Additionally, as exhibited in Fig. 3(c), Zhang et al. [58] reported that SmMn2O5 nanospheres were successfully synthesized utilizing the nanosheet assembly of its precursor under an alkaline environment during the hydrothermal process. Besides, the effect of precursors on the growth of mullite oxides was investigated. Yu et al. [61] reported that anions of precursors had an impact on the growth condition. It was concluded that Cl- ions led to the aggregation of SmMn2O5, while CH3COO- ions contributed to the anisotropy and uniform growth of SmMn2O5. As a result, SmMn2O5 nanoparticles were formed with the existence of Cl- ions, while SmMn2O5 nanorods were formed with the existence of CH3COO- ions. In addition, Mei et al. [27] found that the acidic environment facilitated the linear growth along one dimension of precursors, and YMn2O5 nanorods were obtained upon reducing the pH value below 4, which is shown in Fig. 3(d). After that, Ma et al. [62] made a further investigation to clarify the effect of the pH value on the morphology of mullite oxides. With the increase of the pH value, the transformation from SmMn2O5 nanorods to SmMn2O5 nanoparticles occurred, accompanied by the increase of the specific surface area from 30.64 m2/g to 66.71 m2/g and the change of exposing crystal surfaces including active (001) and (020) surfaces. Fig. 3(e) shows the SmMn2O5 nanoparticles prepared under the pH value of 9 at 200 ℃ for 12 hours. In addition to hydrothermal methods, other synthesis methods are developed to synthesize mullite oxides with different morphologies. For example, as displayed in Fig. 3(f), Zhang et al. [63] reported that electrospinning methods were used to synthesize YMn2O5 nanofibers with the average diameter of 93 nm. Compared with prepared YMn2O5 powders, the specific surface area of YMn2O5 nanofibers increased from 29.47 m2/g to 42.91 m2/g. Meanwhile, Zhu et al. [57] reported that SmMn2O5 nanofibers, nanotube-in-tubes and porous nanotubes were successfully synthesized via electrospinning methods by regulating the heating-up time, which is shown in Fig. 3(g-h). To introduce large pores into the inner of SmMn2O5, Feng et al. [64] explored various synthesis methods in synthesizing macroporous SmMn2O5. As exhibited in Fig. 3(i), SmMn2O5 nanoparticles with interconnected macropores (> 25 nm) were successfully synthesized via organic solvent combustion methods. It was concluded the evaporation of the mixed organic solution in the calcination led to the formation of macropores in the inner of SmMn2O5. The macropores allowed soot particles to enter and attach to the SmMn2O5 surface for improving the physical contact, contributing to the catalytic removal of soot particles. 3.2 Composition regulation In the study of the thermal stability of metal oxides, it is considered that the local coordination structure of lattice oxygen affects the bonding strength between metal ions and oxygen [65–67]. In Mn-based metal oxides, the long Mn-O bonds perform unstable and tend to create oxygen vacancies by the oxygen loss, accelerating the formation of active oxygen species but driving the phase transition during the reaction process [68,69]. As for AMn2O5, the excellent thermal stability is ascribed to the complex bonding between Mn4+, Mn3+, A-site ions and oxygen, which limits the formation of active oxygen species [42]. Therefore, it is effective to adjust the strength of the Mn-O bonds to obtain the good catalytic activity and thermal stability simultaneously by regulating the composition of mullite oxide catalysts. In the previous study, the A-site cations play an important role in determining the strength of the Mn-O bonds in AMn2O5. For example, Thampy et al. [70] made a comparison between PrMn2O5 and SmMn2O5 to understand the effect of A-site cations on the catalytic performance. The temperature of 50 % NO conversion was 230 ℃ for PrMn2O5 while the same NO conversion was achieved in 275 ℃ for SmMn2O5, indicating that PrMn2O5 exhibited the superior catalytic activity compared to SmMn2O5. More active oxygen species arising from the weaker Mn-O bonds in PrMn2O5 accelerated NO oxidation, which was proved by the O2 temperature-programmed desorption (TPD). Moreover, the effect of A-site cations on the surface electronic structure was investigated by Hu and co-workers [71]. To evaluate the difference in the electronic structures for AMn2O5 (A = Sm, Pr, Y), the DFT calculation was used to obtain the partial density of states. Despite the similar crystal structures for three AMn2O5, the A-site cations caused a distinction in the distance between the Mn 3d band center and the Fermi level. The minimum distance of 0.94 eV was observed in SmMn2O5 implying the stronger adsorption capacity of gaseous O2. As a result, the calculated O2 dissociation barrier for SmMn2O5 was lower than PrMn2O5 and YMn2O5, which is displayed in Fig. 4(a). Elemental doping is regarded as an effective way to tune the oxygen species activity by adjusting the bond strength. In AMn2O5, two types of the doping positions including A-site doping and Mn-site doping have been studied. It is considered that the doping position strongly depends on the size of doped elements. For instance, Feng et al. [76] utilized a co-precipitation method to introduce La ions into the lattice of SmMn2O5, resulting in the formation of LaxSm1-xMn2Oδ, a composite oxide with the mullite phase SmMn2O5 and the Mn-rich perovskite phase La0.96MnO3.05. Because of the larger cationic radius of La3+ ions (1.36 Å) than Sm3+ ions (1.24 Å), the shifting to a lower angle of the two main XRD peaks corresponding to SmMn2O5 was observed in prepared LaxSm1-xMn2Oδ, implying the partial replacement of Sm3+ ions by La3+ ions. The La doping induced the formation of active surface oxygen species by optimizing the bonding at the interface between SmMn2O5 and La0.96MnO3.05, contributing to the improvement of the oxygen species activity. Similarly, Wen et al. [77] reported that SmxLa1-xMn2O5 was prepared by doping La3+ ions into SmMn2O5 via a two-step hydrothermal method. Additionally, Zhao et al. [78] adopted a one-step co-precipitation method to prepare AxSm1−xMn2O5-δ (A = Ca, Sr, Ba) by maintaining the stoichiometric amounts of 1:1:4 for various metal elements (Sm:A:Mn = 1:1:4). The XPS and the EDS characterizations indicated that the ratio of (Sm+A)/Mn was close to 1:2 on the surface and in the bulk, respectively, which represented that the doped elements occupied the partial A-site position in the mullite phase. Meanwhile, some Mn-site doped mullite oxide catalysts have also been reported. For example, Shi et al. [72] prepared SmCe0.1Mn1.9O5 via a sol-gel method and studied the effect of the Ce doping on the crystal structure of SmMn2O5. The Raman spectroscopy was used to determine the doping position and evaluate the variance of bond strength. As shown in Fig. 4(b), compared with the pristine SmMn2O5, it was obvious that the Raman peak representing the antisymmetric stretching vibration of Mn3+-O bonds exhibited some blue shift, while the Raman peak corresponding to the antisymmetric stretching vibration of Mn4+-O bonds remained almost unchanged, which implied that the partial substitution of Ce ions for Mn3+ ions rather than Mn4+ ions occurred during the synthesis process SmCe0.1Mn1.9O5. Furthermore, due to the existence of the Ce3+-O-Mn4+ structure, the observed blue shift of the Mn3+-O stretching vibration demonstrated a reduction in the Mn-O bond strength, which was beneficial to accelerate the transformation from lattice oxygen into active surface oxygen species. In particular, the Mn-site doping is accompanied by the Raman peak splitting. Chen et al. [79] reported that the Raman peak at 670 cm−1 was split into two peaks at 652 cm−1 and 683 cm−1 after doping Pd into the bulk of SmMn2O5. The Raman peak splitting of the Mn3+-O bond vibration served as the definite evidence that Pd ions substituted into Mn3+ ions rather than Mn4+ ions. 3.3 Interfacial decoration A critical aspect of heterogenous catalysts is the surface properties. It is well accepted that the excellent catalytic activity for NO oxidation for the mixed-phase mullite oxide catalyst benefits from the exposed Mn-Mn dimers on the stepped surfaces, in which NO prefers to adsorb on the O-covered Mn-Mn dimers to form Mn-nitrate intermediate species [23]. For other catalytic reactions, in addition to the ability to activate gaseous O2, the distinction in reaction mechanisms may put forward some requirements for mullite oxide catalysts. Therefore, loading other materials on the AMn2O5 surfaces for the optimization of the surface properties is expected to improve the catalytic performance for different catalytic reactions. The adsorption ability of reactant gas or critical intermediate species plays an important role in the catalytic performance of mullite oxide catalysts. For example, Chen et al. [80] explored the reaction mechanism of ammonia selective catalytic oxidation (NH3-SCO) on the SmMn2O5 surface. According to the calculated adsorption energy of gaseous NH3, the surficial Lewis acid site was responsible to adsorb NH3 and produce -NH groups as the critical intermediate. Therefore, loading acidic Nb2O5 on the SmMn2O5 surface was beneficial to increase the population of Lewis acid sites, which facilitated the adsorption of NH3. The NH3 temperature-programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) showed that the increase of NH3 adsorption amount was obtained after loading Nb2O5, contributing to improving the N2 selectivity in NH3-SCO. Additionally, Lang et al. [81] tried to load CuOx on the SmMn2O5 surface to improve the low-temperature activity for carbon monoxide (CO) oxidation. Comprehensive characterizations demonstrated that the loaded CuOx introduced additional adsorption sites for extra CO, facilitating its oxidation by utilizing active oxygen species at the interface between CuOx and SmMn2O5. The formed interfaces between the loaded materials and mullite oxides assist in providing more active oxygen species for catalytic reactions. For instance, Zhang et al. [73] reported that the formed interface between CeO2 and YMn2O5 was beneficial to improve the catalytic activity for propane oxidation. The lattice mismatch between the materials induced the strong interfacial strain, leading to the formation of oxygen vacancies as active centers. As shown in Fig. 4(c), with the CeO2-assisted, the oxygen vacancies accelerated the transformation of lattice oxygen into active oxygen species at the interface, which was conducive to breaking the C-H bonds of propane. Feng et al. [40] reported that highly dispersed Co3O4 nanoparticles were grew on the SmMn2O5 surface via a deposition precipitation method. The interaction between Co3O4 and SmMn2O5 induced the formation of oxygen vacancies at the interface, which enhanced oxygen mobility to accelerate methane oxidation. Besides, the strong interaction between noble metals and mullite oxides has been investigated to tune the electronic structure at the interface. For instance, He et al. [82] adopted a wet impregnation method to load Pt nanoparticles on the YMn2O5/La-Al2O3 surface. After aging for 10 hours at 800 ℃, the TEM characterizations showed that the hydrothermal aging induced the construction of the interface between Pt (111) and YMn2O5 (121) crystal surfaces, accompanied by the creation of oxygen vacancies. The formed oxygen vacancies served as active centers to compensate for the activity loss of the aggregation of Pt nanoparticles, making Pt/YMn2O5/La-Al2O3 perform an excellent hydrothermal stability in NO oxidation. Moreover, Liang et al. [83] reported a new synthesis method to prepare Pt/YMn2O5/Al2O3-SiO2, and explored the effect of the post-treatment on the Pt nanoparticles. During the cyclic treatment of high-temperature oxidation and low-temperature reduction, the strong interaction between the Pt nanoparticles and YMn2O5 led to the atomic arrangement at the interface, reducing the average size of the Pt nanoparticles from 8.5 nm to 7.3 nm and promoting the formation of active oxygen species. The reduction treatment at 250 ℃ generated abundant defects at the interface, which served as active sites for capturing Pt atoms during the subsequent oxidation treatment at 800 ℃, which assisted in preventing the aggregation of the loaded Pt nanoparticles. The Pt/ YMn2O5/Al2O3-SiO2 sample performed a good catalytic activity for CO/propylene (C3H6)/NO oxidation due to the smaller Pt nanoparticles and more active oxygen species. 3.4 Mixed-phase construction Some inherent performance shortcomings of single-phase mullite oxide catalysts cannot meet the requirements of different catalytic reactions in practical applications. By mixing AMn2O5 with second-phase materials, the synergistic effect of mixed phases contributes to the enhancement of the catalytic performance of mixed-phase oxide catalysts, thus broadening their scope of application in catalytic reactions. The choice of the second-phase materials could be non-metal oxides and metal oxides. For example, Chen et al. [84] reported a mixed-phase oxide catalyst was successfully synthesized by mixing SmMn2O5 with carbon nanotubes or graphene oxides in the hydrothermal process. The synergistic effect between SmMn2O5 and carbon nanotubes/graphene oxides enhanced the catalytic activity for NO oxidation by releasing more heat in different temperature ranges. To obtain the anti-poisoning ability against Cl ions, Liu and co-workers [74] mixed CaO with SmMn2O5 by the ball-milling for 10 minutes to reduce the strong adsorption of Cl ions on the active sites. It was considered that Cao as the second-phase material obtained the electron-donating ability and the strong adsorption ability of inorganic chlorine. As shown in Fig. 4(d), the presence of CaO facilitated the dichlorination process, converting it into hydrogen chloride (HCl) and avoiding chlorine poisoning of the active sites. Meanwhile, the electrons preferred to transfer from CaO to SmMn2O5 resulting in the weaker Mn-O bonds, which promoted the transformation from lattice oxygen into active electrophilic oxygen species for chlorobenzene oxidation. The synergistic effect between SmMn2O5 and CaO contributed to the anti-chloride poisoning ability and the enhancement of the catalytic activity. In addition, the synergistic effect of accelerating electron transfer has been investigated to enhance the electrocatalytic performance of mixed-phase oxide catalysts [85,86]. This effect originates from the electronegative difference between Mn atoms and other atoms with high electronegativity in the second-phase materials. Besides, it has been reported that acid treatment induced the phase transition of Mn-based oxides to in situ prepare mixed-phase oxide catalysts. For example, Guo et al. [87] reported that GdMn2O5/GdMnO3 was successfully synthesized by immersing GdMnO3 into the suitable nitric acid. The disproportionation reaction of Mn3+ ions induced the formation of mullite phase in the precursor. The cooperation between GdMn2O5 and GdMnO3 helped to expose rich Mn4+ ions on the GdMn2O5/GdMnO3 surface, facilitating the activation of gaseous O2 into active oxygen species. Consequently, the prepared GdMn2O5/GdMnO3 sample performed well in the deep oxidation of 2-ethoxyethanol, in which a 50 % conversion was achieved at 198 ℃, being 25 ℃ lower than that of single GdMnO3. 3.5 Acid Treatment It is reported that acid treatment works well in dealloying by immersing alloy materials in the acid solution to remove active components and behind inert ones [88]. Inspired by it, considerable researchers began to adopt this strategy to tune the electronic structure of metal oxides such as Mn-based perovskite oxides. For example, Huang et al. [89] reported that La0.5Sr0.5MnO3 with rich Mn ions on the surface was synthesized via the treatment of nitric acid. This work demonstrates that acid treatment is able to exfoliate selectively partial ions and expose active Mn sites on the Mn-based oxide surface. Besides, some researches report that porous Mn-based oxides can be prepared via acid treatment. For instance, Si et al. [90] reported that a three-dimensionally ordered macroporous (3DOM) γ-MnO2 was successfully synthesized by immersing the 3DOM-LaMnO3 in the nitric acid. The transformation from Mn3+ ions into Mn4+ ions was achieved by the disproportionation reaction of Mn3+ ions under an acidic environment: 2Mn3+ solid → Mn4+ solid + Mn2+ liquid, which was considered to be the selective dissolution principle for the Mn-based oxides under an acidic environment [88,90–92]. Different from perovskite oxides, due to the coexistence of Mn3+ and Mn4+ ions, AMn2O5 exhibits the distinct behavior during the acid treatment. For Mn-based perovskite oxides, the final product MnO2 can be obtained through acid treatment for sufficient time. On the contrary, for Mn-based mullite oxides, the acid treatment cannot completely convert AMn2O5 into MnO2 due to the protection of the original Mn4+ ions on the surface. The existence of Mn4+ ions can form a thin layer of MnO2 on the AMn2O5 surface, preventing the internal mullite phase from the attack of H+ ions under an acidic environment [75,93]. Therefore, it is valuable to study the effect of acid treatment on AMn2O5 for constructing new active centers and tuning the distribution of active centers. It is well known that in AMn2O5, the surfaces terminated by A-site cations exhibit a low chemical activity, whereas the surfaces terminated by Mn cations perform actively in catalytic reactions [70,94]. Due to the longer bonding, acid treatment can selectively remove the A-site cations in AMn2O5, which is conducive to exposing active Mn4+ ions on the surface. For instance, Gao et al. [95] adopted the acid treatment to modify the surface properties of GdMn2O5 for benzene oxidation. During the acid treatment process, the Gd-O bonds, which were longer than the Mn-O bonds in GdMn2O5, were preferentially broken, leading to the exposure of Mn4+ ions and the formation of oxygen vacancies. The abundant oxygen vacancies served as active centers, facilitating the activation of gaseous O2 and enhancing the transformation of lattice oxygen into active surface oxygen species. Besides, the reduction peak shifting to a lower temperature was observed in H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR), implying the improved redox ability of acid-treated GdMn2O5 (denoted as GMO-H). The cooperation between oxygen vacancies and exposed Mn4+ ions in the GMO-H sample contributed to the enhancement of the catalytic activity for benzene oxidation. In addition, acid treatment has emerged as a novel post-treatment for synthesizing composite mullite oxide catalysts. For example, Yang et al. [75] reported that a Mn4+@SmMn2O5 composite mullite oxide catalyst was synthesized by tailoring a SrMnO3@SmMn2O5 precursor with acid treatment. As displayed in Fig. 4(e), they first adopted a sol-gel method to prepare SrMnO3@SmMn2O5 as a precursor, which contained rich Mn ions in the bulk. Subsequently, the nitric acid with 5 mol/L was used to remove the all Sr3+ ions of SrMnO3 and the partial Sm3+ ions of SmMn2O5 surface for the formation of Mn4+@SmMn2O5, which contained abundant Mn4+ ions and oxygen vacancies on the surface. The Mn4+@SmMn2O5 sample exhibited a better diesel oxidation catalyst (DOC) performance, achieving a lower complete conversion temperature for CO and C3H6 by 90 ℃ and a 18 % higher maximum NO conversion at 300 ℃ compared to the pristine SmMn2O5. Moreover, the combination of acid treatment with other modification approaches has been reported to tune the electronic structure of AMn2O5. For example, Yang et al. combined interfacial decoration with acid treatment to synthesize a CeO2/SmMn2O5-H mullite oxide catalyst applied in the DOC. They loaded CeO2 on the SmMn2O5 surface and immersed CeO2/SmMn2O5 into the nitric acid. The redox cycle of Mn3+/Mn4+ was responsible for the adsorption and oxidation of NO, and the redox cycle of Ce3+/Ce4+ activated gaseous O2 to produce active oxygen species. Meanwhile, the acid treatment was conducive to exposing more Ce3+ and Mn4+ ions on the surface, thus facilitating the above redox cycle Ce3+ + Mn4+ → Ce4+ + Mn3+. The synergistic effect between the interfacial decoration and the acid treatment contributed to the enhancement of the DOC performance of CeO2/SmMn2O5-H, in which the complete oxidation of CO and C3H6 was only 250 ℃ and the maximum conversion of NO reached 68 % at approximately 300 ℃. In summary, the complex crystal structure of AMn2O5 offers possibilities to enhance the catalytic performance for various chemical reactions. The understanding on different modification strategies plays a crucial role as they facilitate the rational design of heterogeneous catalysts. In the following content, these modification approaches applied in Mn-based mullite oxide catalysts would be discussed in catalytic treatment of vehicle exhaust and catalytic oxidation of VOCs. 4 Vehicle exhaust treatment application Catalytic oxidation has been extensively applied as an efficient strategy for removing pollutants from vehicle exhaust, including NOx, NH3, soot particles, CO and methane [7]. However, the complex reaction atmosphere in vehicle exhaust, as well as the increasingly stringent emission standards put forwards stringent requirements on the catalysts, enforcing researchers to design non-previous metal materials suitable for diverse practical working conditions. To overcome the complexity arising from different pollutants, the influence of other substances such as NOx and steam, plenty of studies have been carried out to boost the low-temperature activity, selectivity and durability of mullite oxide catalysts [79–82,96–98]. The pristine and modified mullite oxide catalysts, applied modification strategies and corresponding catalytic performance for various pollutants from vehicle exhaust are listed in Table 2. 4.1 Nitrogen monoxide oxidation In diesel engines, the lean burn condition causes a large amount of NOx in the exhaust, of which NO accounts for nearly 90 % [93,99]. It is well accepted that NO2 with high oxidizing ability helps the catalytic oxidation of hydrocarbons and soot particles in exhaust after-treatment lines [63,96]. Therefore, the oxidation of NO into NO2 plays an important role in controlling the emission of NOx and removing other pollutants from vehicle exhaust. Inspired by the seminal work of Wang and co-workers, the structure-property relationship of AMn2O5 has been thoroughly investigated using NO oxidation as the model reaction, paving the way for the further development of mullite oxide catalysts. Shan and co-workers [24] conducted a comprehensive study on the catalytic behavior SmMn2O5 in NO oxidation, suggesting that the MvK and the ER mechanisms both contributed to NO oxidation. The exposed Mn4+ ions with the strong redox ability, served as active centers along the MvK and the ER mechanisms. Thus, increasing the population of exposed Mn4+ ions on the AMn2O5 surface is an effective way to enhance the catalytic activity for NO oxidation, and a straightforward way is to modify the morphology of AMn2O5 to enlarge the specific surface area, thereby creating more active sites on the surface. For instance, Wang et al. [99] investigated the effect of the Mn-based precursor on the morphologies of AMn2O5. After comparing three Mn-based precursors including Mn(CH3COO)2, MnCl2, and Mn(NO3)2, they found that a flower-like SmMn2O5 mullite oxide with a specific surface area of 134.25 m2/g was successfully synthesized using Mn(NO3)2 as the precursor via a hydrothermal method. The large specific surface area was conducive to exposing more Mn4+ ions as active centers on the surface, which made the flower-like SmMn2O5 sample obtain a lower temperature of 50 % NO conversion (230 ℃) and a higher maximum conversion efficiency (81 % NO conversion at 282 ℃), being superior to other samples. According to the previous studies, the Sm-terminated crystal surfaces of SmMn2O5 showed inactive in NO oxidation [70,94]. Therefore, as depicted in Fig. 5(a), Yang et al. [93] adopted acid treatment to selectively exfoliate the partial inactive Sm3+ ions for the exposure of active Mn4+ ions on the SmMn2O5 surface. The selective removal of Sm3+ ions was ascribed to the difference in the bond strength, in which the Sm-O bonds (2.42 Å) were longer than the Mn3+-O bonds (1.97 Å) and the Mn4+-O bonds (1.95 Å) in SmMn2O5, which is shown in Fig. 5(b). This phenomenon implied that the Sm-O bonds owned higher surface energy and were easier to break. The XPS characterizations showed that the ratio of Sm/Mn decreased and the ratio of Mn4+/Mn3+ increased in the acid-treated SmMn2O5, indicating that the removal of Sm3+ions and the exposure of Mn4+ ions were achieved simultaneously via the acid treatment. As shown in Fig. 5(c), the temperature of 80 % NO conversion in the acid-treated SmMn2O5 was 280 ℃, being 45 ℃ lower than that of the pristine SmMn2O5. Utilizing the soft X-ray adsorption characterizations and the DFT calculation, Wang and co-workers [17] proposed that the p-d hybridization can be used as a descriptor to evaluate the catalytic activity of AMn2O5 for NO oxidation and elemental doping can regulate the Mn-O bond strength by modifying the p-d hybridization. Moreover, Yang et al. [35] adopted the microkinetic analysis to explore the effect of doping elements on the Mn-O bond strength. It was concluded that elemental doping such as Sr doping and La doping was conductive to lowering the Mn-O bond, promoting the activation of gaseous O2 via the ER mechanism. These studies demonstrate that elemental doping can effectively tune the chemical activity of oxygen species in AMn2O5. For instance, Feng et al. [76] reported that the La doping induced the formation of La0.96MnO3.05 in SmMn2O5. The cooperation between the original SmMn2O5 and the formed La0.96MnO3.05 created oxygen vacancies at the surface. The formed oxygen vacancies assisted in destabilizing the intermediate species nitrite/nitrate to facilitate the desorption of NO2, which was regarded as the rate-determining step in NO oxidation. The best-doped sample exhibited a good catalytic activity with a maximum NO conversion of 85 % at 290 ℃, while the pristine SmMn2O5 sample only obtained a maximum NO conversion of 78 % at 320 ℃. Besides, He et al. [97] reported that the Pt/doped-mullite monolithic catalysts exhibited the outstanding catalytic activity and thermal stability in NO oxidation. The authors made a partial substitution of low-valence Mg2+ ions with high-valence Sm3+ ions in SmMn2O5 and then mixed it with commercial La-Al2O3 by ball-milling to prepare a mixed support. Subsequently, Pt nanoparticles were loaded on the mixed support via an impregnation method and the powdered sample was loaded on the cylindrical cordierite to synthesize a Pt/Mg-SMO-LA monolithic catalyst. Under the simulated diesel vehicle, the Pt/Mg-SMO-LA sample achieved a 30 % NO conversion at 261 ℃ and maintained the loss of NO maximum conversion less 3 % after the hydrothermal aging at 800 ℃ for 16 hours, which was expected to be applied in industrial applications. Comprehensive characterizations revealed that the good catalytic performance was attributed to the abundant oxygen vacancies, induced by the non-equivalent doping of Mg2+ ions. The created oxygen vacancies facilitated the NO oxidation cycle by reducing the competitive adsorption of NO and O2 at the Pt and Mn sites. As shown in Fig. 6(a), it was observed that the accumulation of nitrite species (1318, 1198 cm−1) and nitrate species (1570, 1552, 1226 cm−1) occurred in NO or NO + O2 atmosphere. Besides, the enhancement of NO2 species (1617 cm−1) in NO atmosphere meant the consume of oxygen vacancies and the generation of NO2. These phenomena indicated that the LH mechanism and the cooperative MvK mechanism both contributed to NO oxidation in Pt/Mg-SMO-LA. As depicted in Fig. 6(b), the cooperation between oxygen vacancies with Pt and Mn active sites led to the composite reaction mechanism. 4.2 Ammonia selective catalytic reduction/oxidation In treatment of vehicle exhaust, ammonia selective catalytic reduction (NH3-SCR) is applied in the upstream after-treatment system to convert NOx into nitrogen (N2) using urea as a reducing agent [105,106]. This reaction aims to control the emission of NOx from vehicle exhaust. However, due to the excess urea dosing, an excessive amount of NH3 is inevitably introduced into the exhaust steam. To address NH3 slip, NH3-SCO is employed in the downstream after-treatment system to eliminate excess NH3 emissions. During this process, NH3 is selectively oxidized into non-toxic N2 [80,107]. It is considered that the selectivity to N2, the low-temperature activity as well as the compatibility with other catalytic converter operating temperature are critical targets for catalysts applied in NH3-SCR/SCO. Due to the strong activation ability of NO, AMn2O5 is regarded as a promising material candidate for NH3-SCR/SCO. The tunability of electronic structure of AMn2O5 offers opportunities to further improve its N2 selectivity, low-temperature activity, and temperature window. It is important to reveal the catalytic behavior of AMn2O5 for NH3-SCR/SCO. Based on the first-principle microkinetic study, Chen et al. [46] clarified the structure-property relationship of SmMn2O5 for NH3-SCO under experimentally operating conditions. They proposed that Mn-Mn dimers and lattice oxygen served as the descriptors to evaluate selectivity and activity of SmMn2O5, respectively. For the active (010)4+ crystal surface, the cooperation between Mn-Mn dimers and O2-O2 channels performed well in the conversion of NH3 and the production of N2. During the reaction process, Mn-Mn dimers facilitated the adsorption of NH3 contributing to the high N2 selectivity, and O2-O2 channels assisted in the migration of lattice oxygen and the activation of adsorbed NH3 contributing to the good low-temperature activity. This work provides new insights into the rational design of mullite oxide catalysts with excellent performance. For NH3-SCR, Wang et al. [105] adopted a modified acid treatment to exfoliate the inert Sm3+ ions and induce the exposure of the Mn-Mn dimers and the Mn-O sites as the dual active sites on the SmMn2O5 surface (denoted as SM-E) for the improvement of catalytic activity. The SM-E sample performed an excellent low-temperature activity and N2 selectivity in NH3-SCR, where a 98 % NOx conversion was achieved at only 90 ℃ and more than 80 % N2 selectivity remained in a wide temperature range from 90 ℃ to 200 ℃. The improved catalytic performance was ascribed to the formed dual active sites, in which the Mn-Mn dimers activated NO into the nitrite species and the Mn-O sites were responsible for the adsorption of NH3. The cooperation of this dual active sites assisted in reducing the competitive adsorption of NO and NH3 at the active sites. For NH3-SCO, Chen et al. [80] proposed that enhancing the adsorption of NH3 on the SmMn2O5 surface was conducive to the N2 selectivity in NH3-SCO. Based on the DFT calculation, the imide mechanism contributed to NH3-SCO in SmMn2O5, in which the adsorbed NH3 gradually converted into -NH groups, subsequently one -NH group reacted with one -HNO group to form N2. To further enhance the N2 selectivity, the acidic amorphous Nb2O5 was loaded on the SmMn2O5 surface to create rich Lewis acid sites. As shown in Fig. 7(a), the loaded acidic Nb2O5 assisted in producing -NH groups by attracting the lone-pair electron of the N atom in NH3, facilitating the production of N2. Thus, the best sample performed 68 % N2 selectivity at 180 ℃, while the N2 selectivity was only 53 % at 180 ℃ in the pristine SmMn2O5. Except for the imide reaction mechanism, the internal selective reduction mechanism (i-SCR) was also proposed for NH3-SCO, in which NH3 was first oxidized to NOx and subsequently converted into N2. Dong et al. [108] synthesized a SmMn2O5/Cu-SAPO34 mixed-phase oxide catalyst by grinding powder mixtures. As displayed in Fig. 7(b), the synergistic effect between SmMn2O5 with the remarkable oxidation properties and Cu-SAPO34 with the active reduction properties was conducive to the enhancement of the low-temperature activity and N2 selectivity, in which a 90 % NH3 conversion was achieved at 215 ℃, and the N2 selectivity was significantly higher than that of the pristine SmMn2O5 above 215 ℃. 4.3 Soot combustion The incomplete combustion of engine fuel usually causes the formation of particulate matters in vehicle exhaust, which are mainly composed of soot particles and adsorbed substances [109]. It is reported that the temperature in vehicle exhaust from diesel engines ranges from 200 to 500 ℃, which is below the threshold required by direct combustion of soot particles, typically exceeding 600 ℃ [64,110]. One major challenge is reducing the reaction temperature to effectively remove soot particles from vehicle exhaust. With the assistance of NOx, AMn2O5 with the high thermal stability is expected to complete the catalytic oxidation of soot particles below 500 ℃. However, the poor physical contact with soot particles and the weak redox ability of AMn2O5 mullite oxides limit their practical applications in soot combustion. According to the literature, the size of soot particles usually exceeds 25 nm [111]. Therefore, the design of AMn2O5 with enough large pores allowing soot particles to diffuse is able to improve the physical contact between soot particles and catalysts. For example, Chen et al. [55] reported that the colloidal crystal template method was able to synthesize SmMn2O5 mullite oxides with controllable pores by tuning the size of templates, as displayed in Fig. 8(a). They chose carboxyl-modified poly(methyl methacrylate) (CPMMA) as the template, which had the proper glass transition temperature and decomposition temperature, ensuring the 3DOM structure was formed before the removal of the CPMMA template. As exhibited in Fig. 8(b), the morphologies at different synthesis stages indicated that the uniform and regular pores with 290 nm diameter were successfully formed in SmMn2O5. These large pores promoted the diffusion of soot particles on the SmMn2O5 surface for strengthening the physical contact. The 3DOM-SmMn2O5 sample exhibited a 90 % conversion of soot particles at 413 ℃ with NOx-assisted, being 105 ℃ lower than that of the pristine SmMn2O5 sample. It is reported that adsorbed NO2 performs a higher chemical activity than gaseous NO2 when reacting with soot particles. Therefore, Chen et al. [96] proposed that enhancing the adsorption ability to NO2 was beneficial to reduce the reaction temperature of soot combustion. They modified the surface of SmMn2O5 with K-based composite oxides, which owned the strong electropositivity and served as the actives sites to adsorb NO2 [112,113]. The KNO3 was added into the mullite precursor to in situ grow K2Mn4O8 on the surface of 3DOM-SmMn2O5, obtaining the 3DOM-K2Mn4O8/SmMn2O5 mullite oxide supported catalyst. As displayed in Fig. 8(c), gaseous NO could react with surficial oxygen species of 3DOM-K2Mn4O8/SmMn2O5 for forming adsorbed NO2 on the surface. Additionally, the modified K2Mn4O8 could assist in inhibiting the desorption of adsorbed NO2. Compared with the pristine SmMn2O5, the 3DOM-K2Mn4O8/SmMn2O5 had a stronger adsorption ability to NO2, thus facilitating the redox reaction between soot particles and adsorbed NO2. As a result, the 3DOM-5 %K2Mn4O8/SmMn2O5 sample performed a better catalytic activity, in which 90 % soot conversion and 99 % carbon dioxide (CO2) selectivity with NOx-assisted were achieved at 383 ℃. In order to improve the intrinsic redox ability, Jin et al. [100] adopted a sol-gel method to prepare a Ag-SmMn2O5 composite mullite oxide catalyst for soot combustion. The atomically dispersion of Ag produced a reverse oxygen spillover effect for improving the chemical activity of oxygen species. On the one hand, the modified Ag promoted the formation of oxygen vacancies, accelerating the production of adsorbed oxygen species Ox n-. On the other hand, the modified Ag could serve as active centers to activate gaseous O2 for producing active oxygen species, thus facilitating the oxidation of soot particles. With the assistance of NOx, the best Ag-SmMn2O5 sample performed 90 % soot conversion and 99.9 % CO2 selectivity at 413 ℃ at the gas hourly space velocity of 100000 h−1, being 38 ℃ lower than that of the pristine SmMn2O5 sample. 4.4 Carbon monoxide oxidation CO oxidation has always been a critical reaction in the emission control of pollutants from vehicle exhaust [101,114]. It is reported that a large portion of untreated CO is emitted into the atmosphere during the initial cold-start transients, which accounts for a significant fraction of the total CO emission [115]. Therefore, it is necessary to improve the low-temperature activity of catalysts for controlling CO emissions. The excellent chemical durability makes AMn2O5 a potential candidate for the catalytic oxidation of CO compared with other complex metal oxides. However, the weak CO adsorption on the Mn sites leads to the poor catalytic activity of the pristine AMn2O5 below 100 ℃. Loading active components on the AMn2O5 surface is an effective way to modify the surface properties by interfacial decoration. One representative work was reported by Lang et al., [81] in which they adopted a desorption precipitation method to load transition metal oxides on the SmMn2O5 surface, forming MOx/SmMn2O5 (M = Fe, Mn, Co, Ni, Cu) mullite oxide supported catalysts. As shown in Fig. 9(a), among all prepared samples, the CuOx/SmMn2O5 sample performed a superior catalytic activity than others, where the temperature of 50 % CO conversion was 102 ℃ and the reaction rate at 100 ℃ was 5.15 μmol·g−1·s−1. Due to the strong CO adsorption capacity of Cu, it was considered that the loaded CuOx provided additional active sites to adsorb extra CO. As displayed in Fig. 9(b), compared with the pristine SmMn2O5, the higher CO adsorption amount in CuOx/SmMn2O5 promoted CO oxidation by forming another reaction route. Besides, the strong interaction between CuOx and SmMn2O5 improved the reducibility of oxygen species at the interface, accelerating the decomposition of intermediate species. Moreover, Liu et al. [102] proposed that a bifunctional interface was established in the Pt/SmMn2O5 mullite oxide supported catalyst, which provided spatially separated active sites for CO and O2. As exhibited in Fig. 10(a), the TEM characterizations indicated that Pt nanoclusters grew uniformly on the SmMn2O5 surface by the atomic layer deposition (ALD) technology. As displayed in Fig. 10(b), the DFT calculation revealed that CO molecules initially adsorbed on the Pt sites, and O2 molecules were activated on the exposed Mn-Mn dimers to form active oxygen species at the interface. The cooperation between the Pt sites and the Mn-Mn dimers alleviated the CO poisoning on the Pt sites and contributed to an excellent low-temperature catalytic activity in CO oxidation, in which the temperature of 50 % CO conversion was only 86 ℃ in the Pt/SmMn2O5 sample, being lower than most Pt-based catalysts. Furthermore, to clarify the electronic interaction at this bifunctional interface, Liu et al. [47] employed the DFT calculation to investigate the electron transfer between the Pt sites and the Mn-Mn dimers within their proposed catalyst structure. The robustness of the Pt/Mn2 trimer was demonstrated whatever the size of loaded Pt particles, indicating that Pt atoms energetically favored interacting with the Mn-Mn dimers on the SmMn2O5 surface. As shown in Fig. 10(c), the differential charge analysis of the Pt/Mn2 trimer strongly supported the strong electronic interaction between the Pt sites and the Mn-Mn dimers. It was proposed that the electrons transfer from the Pt sites to the Mn-Mn dimers led to the strong polarization of the Mn-Mn dimers, thereby enhancing the activation ability of gaseous O2. 4.5 Methane oxidation Methane (CH4) is a non-polar molecular containing four identical C-H bonds with a high bond energy of 435 kJ·mol−1 [79]. Due to the difficulty of breaking the C-H bond, the complete oxidation of CH4 into non-polluting CO2 and H2O remains a huge challenge, which requires an extremely high reaction temperature (> 600 ℃) [40]. It is reported that Pd-based catalysts are widely used in catalytically oxidizing CH4 gas [116–118], and the chemical properties of supports affects the catalytic activity of Pd-based catalysts [119,120]. The coexistence of multiple crystal fields makes AMn2O5 possess abundant lattice oxygen, making it a promising support material to modify the electronic structure of the Pd sites at the interface. It is valuable to investigate the generated synergistic effect of Pd and AMn2O5 for the understanding of the catalytic behaviors in CH4 oxidation. It is considered that the strong metal-support interaction can affect the redox cycle at the interface when loading Pd nanoparticles on the AMn2O5 surface. For example, Li et al. [104] explored the interaction between Pd and YMn2O5 by analyzing the change of valence state of the Mn and Pd ions during the process of CH4 oxidation. As shown in Fig. 11(a), the in situ XPS characterizations demonstrated the electron transfer between the Pd and Mn sites, in which the electrons transferred from the Pd sites to the Mn site causing the reduction of Mn4+ ions in the oxidizing atmosphere (i.e. CH4+O2), while the oxidation of Mn3+ ions occurred in the reducing atmosphere (i.e. CH4) with the electron transfer from the Mn sites to the Pd sites. This result also implied that the lattice oxygen participated in CH4 oxidation, in which the reduction of PdOx led to the formation of oxygen vacancies at the interface, while the oxygen vacancies were filled up by activating gaseous O2 to achieve the regeneration of PdOx. As depicted in Fig. 11(b), for Pd/YMn2O5, the cooperation between the PdOx and the reducible Mn ions as the dual active sites promoted the electron and oxygen transfer cycle, thus enhancing the catalytic activity for CH4 oxidation. Besides, the electron transfer between the Pd and Mn sites was also reported by Ding et al. [103], in which they adopted the DFT calculation to analyze the charge distribution at the Pd/SmMn2O5 interface. The Bader charge analysis revealed that the positive charge was obtained in the Pd sites, implying that the electrons transferred from the Pd sites to the Mn sites at the interface, thereby facilitating the activation ability of gaseous O2. The prepared Pd/SmMn2O5 sample performed a 50 % CH4 conversion at 328 ℃, being superior to that of Pd/SmMnO3 and Pd/LaMnO3 samples. In addition, Chen et al. [79] proposed that the electronic interaction between the PdOx and the Mn ions in the bulk was expected to improve the adsorption and activation ability of CH4 by constructing new active centers. As depicted in Fig. 12(a), they utilized a sol-gel method to synthesize a Pd-doped SmMn2-xPdxO5 composite mullite oxide as a precursor. Subsequently, the acid treatment with an oxalic acid was used to synthesize a Sm1-yMn2-xPdxO5 catalyst (denoted as SMPO-OA) by removing surficial Sm3+ ions and constructing active phase PdOx. on the surface. The SMPO-OA sample achieved a 90 % CH4 conversion at 334 ℃, being superior to the Pd/SmMn2O5 sample (denoted as 1 Pd/SMO) prepared by an impregnation method. Comprehensive characterizations revealed that new active center Mn4+-O-PdOx was formed on the surface through the combination of the partial substitution of Pdx+ ions to Mn3+ ions with the A-site cation exfoliation. As shown in Fig. 12(b), it was difficult to activate the C-H bond in 1 Pd/SMO at low temperatures. Instead, due to more PdOx on the surface, the exposed Mn4+-O-PdOx active centers can activate the C-H bond at 200 ℃, thus improving the low-temperature catalytic activity for CH4 oxidation in SMPO-OA sample. 5 Volatile organic compounds treatment application VOCs refer to a group of organic compounds with low boiling points (<250 ℃) under the ambient pressure of 101.325 kPa including aromatic compounds, hydrocarbons, ketones compounds, aldehyde compounds and so on, most of which are toxic to the human body and environment [121–123]. Compared with other Mn-based oxides, AMn2O5 with the complex coordinated environment of Mn ions has shown potential advantages in catalytic oxidation of VOCs. For instance, Chen et al. [124] made a comparison among four Mn-based oxides including SmMn2O5 mullite oxides, SmMnO3 perovskite oxides, Mn3O4 spinel oxides, and Mn2O3 bixbyite oxides, to investigate the difference between catalytic behaviors. It was observed that SmMn2O5 performed a better catalytic activity in ethanol oxidation, where the complete oxidation temperature was only 175 ℃, being lower than other Mn-based oxides. According to the crystal field theory, it was considered that the electronic distribution of SmMn2O5 was affected by the spitting of the Mn 3d orbital, arising from the coexistence of diverse crystal fields. The electrons in Mn3+ ions preferentially occupied the d z 2 orbital, enhancing the adsorption ability of gaseous molecules on the SmMn2O5 surface. Therefore, researchers have been drawing attention to the applications of mullite oxides in catalytic oxidation of VOCs due to the distinct crystal structure. However, the type of emitted VOCs appears to affect the catalytic activity of catalysts [125]. Besides, the negative effect of steam, mixed VOCs, and toxic substances such as chloride on the catalytic performance, remains an urgent problem in practical applications [74,126,127]. To solve these problems, some modification strategies have been developed to improve the catalytic performance of mullite oxide catalysts. We have made a detailed survey about the catalytic performance and applied modification strategies of mullite oxide catalysts for various VOCs, which are listed in Table 3. 5.1 Aromatic compounds oxidation Aromatic compounds represent a typical class of VOCs generated in the industrial process, which are toxic to the human body and wider environmental problems such as photochemical smog [133,134]. Catalytic oxidation is an efficient technique to control the emission of aromatic compounds and the efficiency strongly depends on the performance of used catalysts [135]. Compared with other complex metal oxides, AMn2O5 with abundant oxygen species demonstrates promising potential to catalytically oxidize aromatic compounds into CO2 and H2O. Up to now, plenty of studies have been carried out to discover the structure-property relationship and improve the activity and anti-poisoning ability of mullite oxide catalysts in practical applications. To identify active oxygen species, Wan et al. [30] studied the role of oxygen species in SmMn2O5 and studied its catalytical behavior in toluene oxidation. Comprehensive characterizations demonstrated that the low-coordinated surface oxygen species performed actively on the SmMn2O5 surface, which was defined as the labile oxygen species. This labile oxygen species played a critical role in oxidizing toluene. Based on the in situ DRIFTS results, it was speculated that the labile oxygen species preferred to contact with the methyl and assisted in converting the benzene ring into the short carbon-chains, leading to the rapid oxidation of toluene on the SmMn2O5 surface. In addition, Shen et al. [129] combined elemental doping and acid treatment to synthesize a Cu-doped SmMn2O5 composite mullite oxide catalyst (denoted as Cu-SM-E), aiming to produce more active oxygen species. The substitution of Mn3+ ions in the lattice of SmMn2O5 with smaller Cu2+ ions was realized during the hydrothermal process, leading to the formation of Cu2+-O-Mn4+ active sites. The acid treatment with dilute nitric acid was used to break the Sm-O bonds, exposing the new active sites on the surface. As shown in Fig. 13(a), according to the calculated O2 adsorption energies and the oxygen vacancy formation energies, the Cu-SM-E sample obtained the stronger adsorption ability of gaseous O2 and prompted the formation of oxygen vacancies on the surface with the assistance of Cu2+-O-Mn4+ active sites. Meanwhile, Fig. 13(b) displayed that the Raman peak representing the vibration of the Mn3+-O bonds in Cu-SM-E sample was blue-shifted, indicating that the Cu2+-O-Mn4+ active sites helped to weaken the Mn3+-O bonding. The synergistic effect between Cu doping and acid treatment facilitated the production of active oxygen species on the surface. Besides, they explored the possible surface oxidation mechanism of toluene over the Cu-SM-E sample and the pristine sample as depicted in Fig. 13(c). It was inferred that the oxidation of the methyl group on the benzene ring was affected by the surficial oxygen species of catalysts, in which toluene underwent a series of transformations upon contacting with oxygen species. Initially, toluene was converted to the benzyl alcohol by the surface lattice oxygen. Subsequently, the formed benzyl alcohol was further oxidized into a few of intermediate species including the benzaldehyde, benzoic acid, benzene anion, maleic anhydride, eventually leading to the formation of CO2 and H2O. In this process, the Cu2+-O-Mn4+ active sites enabled the benzaldehyde and the benzoic acid to consume quickly compared with the single active Mn ions. The Cu-SM-E sample performed a 90 % toluene conversion at 206 ℃, being 25 ℃ lower than that of the pristine SmMn2O5 sample (denoted as SM). These studies emphasize the importance of oxygen species and indicate that it is possible to enhance the catalytic activity of mullite oxide catalysts by improving the oxygen species activity. For other aromatic compounds, Wang and co-workers [126] reported that a porous SmMn2O5 mullite oxide was synthesized by in situ dismutation method (denoted as SmMn2O5-ID). They chose SmMnO3 perovskite oxide as a precursor and utilized the disproportionation reaction of Mn3+ ions to transform SmMnO3 into SmMn2O5 by immersing the precursor in the 40 mL absolute ethanol with 2.4 mL concentrated nitic acid at room temperature. The SmMn2O5-ID sample performed a 90 % benzene conversion at 265 ℃ while the pristine SmMn2O5 only performed a 90 % benzene conversion at 344 ℃. The removal of partial Sm3+ ions and dismutation of Mn3+ ions facilitated the exposure of Mn4+ ions on the surface, contributing to the enhancement of the redox ability of the SmMn2O5-ID sample. The abundant Mn4+ ions assisted in the migration of lattice oxygen and the production of active oxygen species, thus boosting the catalytic oxidation of benzene on the surface. Besides, this SmMn2O5-ID sample can achieve the complete mineralization of benzene and chlorobenzene above 350 ℃, showing potential in catalytic oxidation of mixed VOCs. Furthermore, they explored the effect of nitric acid on the surface composition for the synthesis of a SmMnO3@SmMn2O5 mixed-phase oxide [128]. By changing the concentration of nitric acid, the acid strength of SmMnO3@SmMn2O5 can be regulated to improve the anti-poisoning ability of chlorine-containing species [128]. As shown in Fig. 14(a), the NH3-TPD results indicated that the SmMnO3@SmMn2O5 sample prepared by 1.2 mL concentrated nitric acid (denoted as SMPM-1.2) obtained the highest NH3 adsorption amount and strongest acid sites. In Fig. 14(b), compared with other samples, the SMPM-1.2 sample exhibited an exceptional anti-chloride poisoning ability, maintaining no activity decay in chlorobenzene oxidation for nearly 20 hours. This remarkable performance was ascribed to the improved acid strength on the surface. As displayed in Fig. 14(c), the mechanism of resistance to chloride poisoning involved the preferential interaction between the acid sites and the Cl in chlorobenzene, leading to the conversion of the Cl into HCl gas. This avoided the strong adsorption of chloride at the oxygen vacancies. The residual oxygen vacancies on the SmMnO3@SmMn2O5 surface activated gaseous O2 to produce active oxygen species, promoting the catalytic oxidation of the remaining organic hydrocarbons into CO2 and H2O. 5.2 Propane oxidation Propane (C3H8) is a typical light alkane existing in both vehicle and natural gas [136,137], and the catalytic oxidation of C3H8 is usually regarded as a model reaction to evaluate the catalytic activity of catalysts [138]. Due to the stable C-C bond (370.3 kJ mol−1) and C-H bond (CH2: 4105.5 kJ mol−1; CH3: 418.0 kJ mol−1) [139], it remains a great challenge to design efficient catalysts capable of achieving the low-temperature (below 300 ℃) removal of C3H8 [140]. Zhang et al. [42] adopted a hydrothermal method to synthesize a YMn2O5 mullite oxide catalyst for C3H8 oxidation, which was able to completely oxidize C3H8 at 275 ℃. The good low-temperature catalytic activity makes YMn2O5 show much potential for deep decomposition of light alkane. To reveal the reaction mechanism, the combination of the in situ characterization technique with the DFT calculation was used to study possible reaction routes. The acrylate species were identified as the key intermediate species in the process of C3H8 oxidation, suggesting that YMn2O5 followed the acrylate reaction route, which was recognized as an efficient reaction route for C3H8 oxidation in the previous literatures [140,141]. Based on this reaction route, the terminal C-H bond in C3H8 reacted with the labile oxygen species on the YMn2O5 surface, leading to the formation of isopropyl. Subsequently, with the cleavage of four C-H bonds, the acylate species were formed and gradually oxidized to CO2 and H2O. The labile oxygen species on the YMn2O5 surface played a critical role in the activation of the C-H bonds in C3H8. Therefore, many researchers pay attention to various modification strategies for improving oxygen species activity of AMn2O5 to further lower the removal temperature of C3H8. The morphology of mullite oxide catalysts has a great impact on the exposed crystal surface and the specific surface area, thereby determining the population of active oxygen species on the surface. For example, Li et al. [56] developed a microwave-assisted hydrothermal method to synthesize a leaf-like SmMn2O5 mullite oxide with a large specific surface area of 122 m2/g. In contrast, the specific surface area of SmMn2O5 prepared via a conventional hydrothermal method was significantly lower at only 30 m2/g. The increase of the specific surface area was beneficial to expose more active oxygen species on the surface. Meanwhile, the anisotropic growth of the crystal surface in SmMn2O5 contributed to the exposure of the (001) crystal surface, which derived from the extra energy of the effective collision between molecules by the microwave radiation. The (001) crystal surface in SmMn2O5 exhibited the lowest oxygen vacancy formulation energy [24], suggesting that the lattice oxygen in this crystal surface was easier to migrate and create oxygen vacancies as active centers for C3H8 oxidation. The leaf-like SmMn2O5 sample performed a 50 % C3H8 conversion at 225 ℃ and an excellent stability at 285 ℃ for 80 hours, which was comparable to those of Pd/Al2O3 catalyst. Moreover, interfacial decoration has been widely used to modify the chemical properties of mullite oxides by loading active components on the surfaces. For example, Zhu et al. [101] proposed that noble metal Pd was impregnated on the SmMn2O5 surface to improve oxygen mobility for C3H8 oxidation. As displayed in Fig. 15(a), the loaded Pd existed in the form of PdOx on the SmMn2O5 surface. The oxygen storage capacity was used to evaluate the amount of active oxygen species, and the Pd/SmMn2O5 sample obtained abundant active oxygen species in the whole temperature range, which is shown in Fig. 15(b). The strong interaction between Pd and SmMn2O5 contributed to the formation and dispersion of active PdOx, facilitating the production of active oxygen species on the surface. In addition, Liu et al. [130] grew Co3O4 on the SmMn2O5 surface through an in situ method to synthesize a Co3O4/SmMn2O5 mullite oxide supported catalyst for C3H8 oxidation. As displayed in Fig. 15(c), Co3O4 nanoparticles were attached to the SmMn2O5 surface for constructing a functional interface. Due to the difference in the work function between Co3O4 and SmMn2O5, the electrons of Co3O4 with a higher work function were driven to transfer to SmMn2O5 with a lower work function at the interface. As depicted in Fig. 15(d), the interfacial electron transfer promoted the transformation of lattice oxygen into active electron-deficient oxygen species O2-x. Compared with the lattice oxygen, the abundant O2-x at the interface facilitated the adsorption and oxidation of C3H8. This feature allows Co3O4/SmMn2O5 to achieve a 90 % C3H8 conversion at 247 ℃ and no deactivation at the extremely high temperature of 800 ℃ for 24 hours, showing both excellent catalytic activity and thermal stability. Ma et al. [53] first reported that acid treatment was able to in situ grow active components on the SmMn2O5 surface for enhancing oxygen mobility. They adopted an ethylene glycol-methanol organic solution combustion method to synthesize an amorphous SmMn2Oy mullite oxide at 700 ℃, and subsequently immersed it in the nitric acid with 0.75 mol/L for 10 minutes to synthesize a MnOx/SmMn2Oy composite mullite oxide catalyst. As displayed in Fig. 15(e), the secondary phase MnOx in situ grew on the amorphous SmMn2Oy surface after the acid treatment. Comprehensive characterizations clarified that the propane oxidation obeyed the formate species mechanism over the MnOx/SmMn2Oy sample due to the cooperation between the MnOx and the SmMn2Oy.
