As depicted in Fig. 15(f), when catalytically oxidizing C3H8, the lattice oxygen of MnOx performed actively to break up the terminal C-H bond in C3H8 boosting the conversion from the C3H8 into the formate species, and the amorphous SmMn2Oy was responsible for the formate decomposition, accompanied by the activation of gaseous O2 to replenish the consumed oxygen species. As shown in Fig. 15(g), the MnOx/SmMn2Oy sample performed a 90 % C3H8 conversion at as low as 237 ℃, showing a better low-temperature catalytic activity than other samples. 5.3 Acetone oxidation Acetone is a typical oxygen-containing VOCs emitted from various industries such as coating, and chemical pharmaceuticals [142]. The catalytic oxidation of acetone is a significant field of study with work paying attention to the catalytic activity and durability of catalysts. AMn2O5 with an excellent thermal stability satisfies the requirement to be a promising catalyst for acetone oxidation. Dong et al. [16] explored the catalytic behavior and reaction mechanism of GdMn2O5 for acetone oxidation. Comprehensive characterizations demonstrated that labile oxygen species were more actively than other lattice oxygen and played a critical role in driving acetone oxidation. Based on the MvK mechanism, the exposed Mn sites on the GdMn2O5 surface served as active sites to adsorb acetone by a carbonyl group. Subsequently, the labile oxygen species attacked the adsorbed acetone and oxidized it into CO2 and H2O, in which the acetate decomposition was regarded as the rate-limiting step. The labile oxygen species on the GdMn2O5 surface played a critical role in acetone oxidation. Therefore, it is considered that improving the reducibility of oxygen species is an effective way to enhance the catalytic performance of mullite oxide catalysts for acetone oxidation. For instance, Zhang et al. have investigated various modification strategies to tune the electronic structure of mullite oxide catalysts for better activity and thermal stability [58,131,132]. They explored the effect of the A-site cations on the distribution of Mn ions in AMn2O5, including Nd3+, Gd3+, La3+, Sm3+, and Y3+ cations occupying the A site [131]. As shown in Fig. 16(a), the SmMn2O5 sample performed a superior catalytic activity than other samples for acetone oxidation, which was ascribed to the highest molar ratio of Mn4+/Mn3+ ions. The exposed Mn4+ ions were conducive to providing more active oxygen species for acetone oxidation. In addition, they utilized the synergistic effect between acid treatment and interfacial decoration to accelerate the acetone decomposition [132]. Acid treatment induced the formation of oxygen vacancies, facilitating the dispersion of loaded components. And CeO2 with good redox ability was deposited on the acid-treated SmMn2O5 surface to improve the redox ability. The prepared best sample achieved a 90 % acetone conversion at 169 ℃, being 63 ℃ lower than that of the pristine SmMn2O5. To further lower the reaction temperature, they optimized the preparation parameters to control the morphology of SmMn2O5 for enlarging the specific surface area [58]. As shown in Fig. 16(b), the nanoflower-like SmMn2O5 mullite oxide (denoted as SMO-NF), which was synthesized with Mn(NO3)2 as a precursor at 220 ℃ for 12 hours during the hydrothermal process, obtained a high specific surface area of 157.32 m2/g. In contrast, the specific surface area of SmMn2O5 prepared by a coprecipitation method was only 61.87 m2/g. The more active sites were obtained on the SMO-NF surface due to the increase of the specific surface area, thus enhancing the catalytic activity for acetone oxidation. The SMO-NF sample was able to completely convert acetone into CO2 and H2O at only 118 ℃ and keep the nearly complete acetone conversion for 36 hours, showing both excellent catalytic activity and durability. 5.4 Ozonation of volatile organic compounds The increasing concentration of ozone (O3), which originated from the photochemical reaction between VOCs and NOx under sunshine, can cause severe environmental hazards [143,144]. It is necessary to develop an efficient purification technique for reducing the emission of O3 and VOCs together. Recently, Wan et al. [145] reported that YMn2O5 exhibited a complete O3 conversion at −5 ℃ and maintained a 48 % O3 conversion after 100 hours at a high relative humidity (RH = 90 %), showing the potential in catalytic removal of O3. Comprehensive characterizations indicated that O3 decomposition followed the ER reaction mechanism on the YMn2O5 surface. The exposed Mn3+ ions, bonding to single coordinated oxygen, served as active sites to decompose O3 into monodentate adsorbed oxygen. The adsorbed oxygen performed actively and assisted in activating VOCs at room temperature. This work strongly supports that the mullite oxide catalyst is a promising candidate for the simultaneous removal of VOCs and O3 together. Based on its unique activity for O3 decomposition, Shen et al. [146] reported that the combination of YMn2O5 with O3 was able to realize the rapid removal of formaldehyde (HCHO) at ambient temperature (-20 ∼ 25 ℃). As shown in Fig. 17(a), with the use of YMn2O5 as catalysts, the conversion of HCHO and O3 both maintained 100 % for nearly 8 hours at −5 ℃ and 25 ℃. To evaluate the purification efficiency at practical application, they designed an air purifier equipped with YMn2O5 coated ceramics for the test. It was observed that the complete decomposition of HCHO and O3 without any secondary pollutant was achieved in a simulated indoor condition. Additionally, Wan et al. [147] explored the potential of the combination of YMn2O5 with O3 for catalytic ozonation of other VOCs. They found that YMn2O5 exhibited a complete oxidation of benzene at 50 ℃ for nearly 30 hours in YMn2O5 with assistance of O3. Furthermore, as depicted in Fig. 17(b), for benzene oxidation, the synergistic effect between Mn4+ ions and Mn3+ ions was formed at the YMn2O5 surface, in which Mn4+ ions served as active sites to adsorb benzene, and Mn3+ ions decomposed O3 to provide active oxygen species for the oxidation of adsorbed benzene. These studies offer an efficient strategy to realize the degradation of VOCs at room temperature, greatly broadening the application prospect of mullite oxide catalysts in the field of heterogeneous catalysis. 6 Summary and outlook The development of rare earth mullite oxide catalysts offers rich opportunities to design next-generation catalysts applied in the environmental protection. Numerous researches have explored the reaction mechanisms and the structure-property relationship of AMn2O5 mullite oxides, as well as understanding the origin of their catalytic performance in various chemical reactions, requiring the integration of advanced characterization technologies and theoretical calculations. In parallel to studying the catalytic behaviors of AMn2O5 mullite oxides, more efforts are needed to concentrate on the design strategies to further enhance the catalytic performance of AMn2O5 mullite oxide catalysts for the stricter emission standards. Given our comprehensive understanding of mullite oxide catalysts, we believe that the further research work deserving to be conducted is as follows: 6.1 Expansion of catalytic reactions The current researches about AMn2O5 mullite oxide catalysts mainly focus on the catalytic treatment of vehicle exhaust and catalytic oxidation of VOCs. Due to the unique crystal structure, AMn2O5 mullite oxide has shown the application potential in other chemical reactions. For instance, Zhang et al. [148] reported that YMn2O5 was able to achieve the fast decomposition of hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) at room temperature, being superior to other reported catalysts. Wang et al. [149] reported that the Li-S battery with SmMn2O5 as the interlayer performed an excellent catalytic activity. Liu et al. [54] studied the application of SmMn2O5 as a CO sensor, which exhibited a fast response/recovery speed (24/28 second toward 40 ppm CO) due to its fast adsorption and electrochemical process of CO. These studies demonstrate the feasibility of AMn2O5 mullite oxides for other catalytic applications beyond the catalytic oxidation of environmental pollutants. 6.2 Research of catalytic oxidation in a multi-component gas mixture Numerous studies mainly pay attention to a single catalytic reaction for evaluating the catalytic performance of mullite oxide catalysts. However, under practical working conditions, the exhaust gas commonly contains a mixture of several components, in which the competitive adsorption occurs on the surface of applied catalysts. Besides, the formed by-products may harm the catalytic performance of catalysts. Therefore, based on the understanding to the catalytic oxidation of single reactants, it is valuable to investigate the catalytic behavior of AMn2O5 mullite oxide catalysts under a multi-component gas mixture, which is expected to promote its further practical application. 6.3 Enhancement of anti-poisoning ability The existence of substances such as H2O or SO2 has been reported to have a negative effect on the catalytic performance of catalysts [7]. In AMn2O5 mullite oxide catalysts, the competitive adsorption between H2O and reactants leads to the decrease of available active sites on its surface [53]. Moreover, the interaction between SO2 and the exposed Mn ions leads to the formation of sulfate species hindering the active sites [150]. Therefore, the susceptibility of AMn2O5 mullite oxides to the poisoning effect limits their practical application. It is necessary to improve the anti-poisoning ability of AMn2O5 mullite oxide catalysts by modifying the surficial structure, which is going to be an important research direction for the future. 6.4 Combination of hybrid modification strategies The main modification strategies applied in mullite oxide catalysts include morphology control, composition regulation, interfacial decoration, mixed-phase construction and acid treatment. However, it is difficult to improve both catalytic activity and other properties through a single modification strategy. Thus, to meet the complex demands of the industry, the combination of hybrid modification strategies has been used to design mullite oxide catalysts with the better catalytic performance. For example, Lu and co-workers [127] adopted a template method to prepare the 3DOM-YMn2O5 as the support material to anchor Pt single atom. Besides, they modified phenyltriethoxysilane as a hydrophobic layer to encapsulate Pt/YMn2O5 for the improvement of the resistance to water. The 3DOM structure provided more active sites on the surface, and anchored Pt single atom promoted the low-temperature reducibility of oxygen species, thereby enhancing the catalytic activity for toluene oxidation. Meanwhile, the encapsulation layer assisted in reducing the competitive adsorption between water and toluene on the active sites, improving the water resistance. Exploring various combinations of hybrid modification strategies allows the innovative design of composite mullite oxide catalysts for practical applications. 6.5 Batch preparation for industry The existing synthesis methods primarily focus on the preparation of small quantities (up to a few grams) of AMn2O5 mullite oxide powder for scientific research. A facile method for batch preparation of AMn2O5 mullite oxides is very urgent to fulfill the industrial demands. The close collaborations between research institutions and commercial companies are expected to promote the mass production of AMn2O5 mullite oxide powder. 6.6 Further study on reaction mechanisms From a theoretical point of view, it is necessary to clarify the reaction mechanism of various catalytic reactions in AMn2O5 mullite oxides. In situ characterization technologies offer insights to study the catalytic behaviors and the reaction mechanisms under the catalytic process. Meanwhile, the development of theoretical calculation facilitates the discovery of potential reaction paths in AMn2O5 mullite oxides under practical conditions. For example, the proposed first-principle microkinetic analysis can evaluate the change of intermediate species as a function of temperature and pressure on the surface of catalysts [35,46]. Furthermore, in situ characterization in combination with theoretical calculation is able to identify active sites and discover possible reaction routes on the AMn2O5 surfaces. For instance, Wang et al. [151] combined the in situ DRIFTS and DFT calculation to clarify the cooperation of Mn-O-Mn-Mn and Co-O-Mn-Mn sites in Co-doped SmMn2O5 mullite oxides for catalytical removal of NOx and chlorinated organic compounds. coredata.dc:description: The development of rare earth catalysts is expected to reduce the dependence on noble metal catalysts in mobile and stationary sources. The AMn2O5 mullite oxide is a category of rare earth metal oxides for the catalytic oxidation of environmental pollutants, in which the A-site cations are the rare earth cations. The coexistence of the diverse Mn ions and the exposed Mn-Mn dimers in AMn2O5 mullite oxides contribute to the excellent catalytic performance for various catalytic reactions. Herein, the crystal structure and the identification of lattice oxygen of AMn2O5 mullite oxides have been discussed. Meanwhile, a comprehensive understanding of the activity and the thermal stability of AMn2O5 mullite oxides has been investigated. As a group of rare earth catalysts, the representing modification strategies with their advantages have been summarized to guide the rational design of next-generation mullite oxide catalysts. To gain a deeper understanding of AMn2O5 mullite oxides as heterogeneous catalysts, we have reviewed the publications in catalytic purification of vehicle exhaust and catalytic oxidation of volatile organic compounds, accompanied by the exploration of corresponding reaction mechanisms and the analysis of applied modification strategies. Furthermore, the perspective research direction of AMn2O5 mullite oxide catalysts has been outlined to inspire more valuable research work.
